question: Growing up, I was such a big fan of ‘The Kid’ I actually called the Kingdome and asked to speak with him. Turns out, I did myself one better: I got to share an outfield with the legend himself, Ken Griffey Jr., after I was drafted by the Cincinnati Reds.

I’m the opposite of Mr. Irrelevant — drafted No. 1 overall — but you can’t exactly say the same about my MLB career. The Mariners will be my third team since breaking in to the big leagues in 2013, and they’ll be hoping I can flash the potential I showed with the Orioles in the second half of 2017.

My only time as a full-time closer came to an end when I broke my hand punching a dugout wall after blowing my second save in three games. But I’ve still got more saves — 19 — than anyone else on the roster, which sets me up to get the first shot at filling the shoes of Edwin Diaz.

I stand about six inches shorter than the lefty I was traded for, but — with a nasty slider headlining my repertoire — baseball evaluators are arguably even more bullish about my potential. Despite my size, I’ve been on scouts’ radars since I became the first Tennessean to be named Gatorade National Baseball Player of the Year back in 2014.

You might know me from my first tenure in Seattle. I wouldn’t blame you if you missed me, though; it lasted only a little longer than it takes for me to swipe a base, which I did 40 times in the first full-time role of my career last season.

You don’t want to step into the box against my triple-digit heater. Mostly because I don’t always seem to know where it’s going. At 22, I was the youngest player in Mets major-league spring training. If I can harness my command in the bullpen, the Mariners hope I’ll show them why.

Having played for three different teams in 2018, I’m getting used to adjusting my head of hair to new ballcaps. With Ben Gamel, Taylor Motter and their glorious gold locks shipped out of town, I heard there was an opening in Seattle for someone with some serious flow. To get a glimpse, you’ll have to catch me with my cap off in the ‘pen.

After toiling in the minors for five years, the White Sox picked me up in the Rule 5 draft. Then it took me another three years to break into the big leagues. But it looks like I’ll finally get my first full-time opportunity for the Mariners this season, after a career-best year at the plate.

After I was drafted out of high school in the third round, my local newspaper declared me “one of the greatest athletes” in the history of my high school. It’s no wonder. Not only did I star in baseball, basketball and football, after being drafted as a shortstop, I’ve since proven to be a reliable arm in the back end of MLB bullpens.
Don’t try to cage my bird. I like to flap my chicken wing as I round the bases every time I go yard — and only Giancarlo Stanton and Nelson Cruz have done so more than I have since 2014.

The next Japanese phenom — Who, you say? Me? As far back as 2009, MLB and NPB teams have been salivating over my left arm. Out of high school, I nearly became the first Japanese player to forgo the Nippon Pro Baseball draft and go directly to MLB but ultimately decided against it. After eight years with the Seibu Lions, I've finally arrived.

I was practically meant to be a Mariner. Even before he traded for me, Jerry Dipoto says he had called me the Mariners’ shortstop of the future. Not only that, but I rocked the navy blue and teal in Little League, too. But, I’ll have to wait to put it on again, as, at least for now, you’ll find me flashing the leather a little south of T-Mobile Park.

I’m no Eddie Gaedel, but I will be the most diminutive Mariner on the active roster when I get the call. Even though I may not stick out of the crowd, you can’t miss my mile-wide smile or help but feel the energy I bring all over the field.

Have you heard of me? Wikipedia hasn’t! I’m the only player on the active roster without a Wikipedia page. Maybe that’s because I’ve never played a major-league game. But I earned my spot on the roster this spring, getting on-base nine times in 20 at-bats and proving my ability to play all over the field.
